name: XVerExtensionMeasure.group.population
title: Cross-Version Extension for FHIR R5:Measure.group.population compared to FHIR R4
description: R5 `Measure.group.population` maps as Equivalent to R4 `Measure.group.population`

element.short: Population criteria
element.definition: A population criteria for the measure.
element.comment: R5 `Measure.group.population` maps as Equivalent to R4 `Measure.group.population`

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.short: Value of extension
element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](extensibility.html) for a list).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for population in measure
element.definition: An identifier that is unique within the Measure allowing linkage to the equivalent population in a MeasureReport resource.
element.comment:
This ''can'' be a meaningful identifier (e.g. a LOINC code) but is not intended to have any meaning.  GUIDs or sequential numbers are appropriate here.

LinkIds can have whitespaces and slashes by design. Tooling should not rely on linkIds being valid XHTML element IDs, and should not directly embed them as such

element.short: initial-population | numerator | numerator-exclusion | denominator | denominator-exclusion | denominator-exception | measure-population | measure-population-exclusion | measure-observation
The human readable description of this population criteria
The criteria that defines this population
element.definition: An expression that specifies the criteria for the population, typically the name of an expression in a library.
element.comment: In the case of a continuous-variable or ratio measure, this may be the name of a function that calculates the value of the individual observation for each patient or event in the population. For these types of measures, individual observations are reported as observation resources included in the evaluatedResources bundle for each patient. See the MeasureReport resource or the Quality Reporting topic for more information.

element.short: A group resource that defines this population
element.definition: A Group resource that defines this population as a set of characteristics.
element.comment: Note that this approach can only be used for measures where the basis is of the same type as the populations (e.g. a Patient-based measure, rather than an Encounter-based measure). In addition, the referenced Group resource SHALL be a definitional (as opposed to an actual) group.

element.short: Which population
element.definition: The id of a population element in this measure that provides the input for this population criteria. In most cases, the scoring structure of the measure implies specific relationships (e.g. the Numerator uses the Denominator as the source in a proportion scoring). In some cases, however, multiple possible choices exist and must be resolved explicitly. For example in a ratio measure with multiple initial populations, the denominator must specify which population should be used as the starting point.

element.short: Aggregation method for a measure score (e.g. sum, average, median, minimum, maximum, count)
element.definition: Specifies which method should be used to aggregate measure observation values. For most scoring types, this is implied by scoring (e.g. a proportion measure counts members of the populations). For continuous variables, however, this information must be specified to ensure correct calculation.
